item.title: Feedback plz
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

aren’t the Java API implementations pretty decent? e.g. dual pivot quicksort, but i could only imagine that it’d be shit in specific edge cases, though it handles certain edge cases well (e.g. using insertion sort for structure sizes less than a specific number)

Read full topic

item.title: Feedback plz
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

I mean it’s there for a reason. There’s only a few, VERY FEW, times I’d ever have to write a custom structure. Otherwise java.lang or java.util all the way. Guava does provide a nice extension to structures you don’t see in the java api.

Read full topic

item.title: Feedback plz
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:27, topic:553909”][quote author=Justin Bieber link=topic=672831.msg4499369#msg4499369 date=1448270515]

[quote author=t4 link=topic=672831.msg4499359#msg4499359 date=1448248074]

pretty cool/easy questions. the fact you can’t use standard libraries is just plain idiocy though.
[/quote]I disagree, since it’s a good exercise for students to re-implement the fundamental data structures and algorithms necessary to support their program, even if it’s as simple as a linked list, queue, etc.

when will you ever do that in the real world? what’s the point? all you need to know is the constraints surrounding them (big o, etc).
[/quote]if u can’t implement a linked list then how are u ever going to implement that quad-weighted binary swinging hash tree??

it’s my understanding zachera is past this point.[/quote]yeah basically

the reason this repo was started to begin with was because my algo instructor’s homework guidelines stating “Do not use any Java packages other than java.math, java.io and java.util.Scanner.” but in reality, how much of industry doesn’t use the Java API?

Read full topic

pretty cool/easy questions. the fact you can’t use standard libraries is just plain idiocy though.
[/quote]I disagree, since it’s a good exercise for students to re-implement the fundamental data structures and algorithms necessary to support their program, even if it’s as simple as a linked list, queue, etc.

when will you ever do that in the real world? what’s the point? all you need to know is the constraints surrounding them (big o, etc).
[/quote]if u can’t implement a linked list then how are u ever going to implement that quad-weighted binary swinging hash tree??[/quote]
A+, i like you

also, im not saying the exercises aren’t valuable… they’re just not valuable for people that have passed CS101. it’s my understanding zachera is past this point.

item.title: Feedback plz
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

Davidi2:

recreating ADT’s in various languages is a pretty standard practice actually. in fact i had a whole class about them for my software development degree and the final project was recreating three different types to meet test cases (was aprox a tier 2-3 class, after we had all passed the oracle java t2 certs to move on; and yes it did also cover algorithms and big-o etc). I see nothing wrong with it being an assignment, it’s a good way to learn the concepts behind data structures and I think it’s dumb to suggest it’s pointless

Read full topic

[quote]These are naive implementations, not intended for production use or specific cases

so whats the point? also, you should probably have function declarations more reusable…[/quote][quote=“z, post:10, topic:553909”][quote author=sini link=topic=672831.msg4499304#msg4499304 date=1448158283]
Writing your own API is kinda pointless unless theres a certain collection you need, or algorithm thats not yet implemented. The amount of optimization that goes into that is bleh.
[/quote]I’m not allowed to use JCF for some programming assignments, but I’m allowed to write my own implementations for these data structures.[/quote]

item.title: Feedback plz
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

github.com

zg/algos/blob/master/Quicksort.java

/**
 * A basic implementation of the quicksort algorithm for integers.
 *
 * @author Zack Zatkin-Gold
 */
public class Quicksort {
    private int[] a;

    private class qsort {
        private void sort(int left, int right) {
            int i = left;
            int j = right;
            int pivot = a[left + (right - left) / 2];
            while(i <= j) {
                while(a[i] < pivot) i++;
                while(a[j] > pivot) j--;
                if(i <= j) {
                    int temp = a[i];
                    a[i] = a[j];
                    a[j] = temp;
This file has been truncated. show original
  • Why is the inner class nested, should probably move the functions to being static.
github.com

zg/algos/blob/master/Set.java

/**
 * A basic set implementation that has insert, read, and insert from other
 * sets for integers.
 *
 * @author Zack Zatkin-Gold
 */
public class Set {
    int idx;
    int length;
    int[] items;

    Set(int length) {
        this.idx = -1;
        this.length = length;
        this.items = new int[length];
    }

    void add(int item) {
        for(int i = 0; i <= idx; i++)
            if(items[i] == item)
This file has been truncated. show original
  • Usage of generics is a bit off. Usually you have an implied case with an array of objects where the condition of the collection is that you only accept the explicit generic type.
github.com

zg/algos/blob/master/Weighted_Quicksort.java

/**
 * A basic implementation of the quicksort algorithm for integers.
 *
 * This will check the weight attribute on each element for comparison
 * in the sorting. An example class edge is used (such as in a graph).
 * An example usage is with Kruskal's algorithm.
 */
public class Weighted_Quicksort {
    private class qsort {
        edge[] a;
        private void sort(int left, int right) {
            int i = left;
            int j = right;
            int pivot = a[left + (right - left) / 2].weight;
            while(i <= j) {
                while(a[i].weight < pivot) i++;
                while(a[j].weight > pivot) j--;
                if(i <= j) {
                    edge temp = a[i];
                    a[i] = a[j];
This file has been truncated. show original
  • Ditto.

General:

  • Please capitalize ALL your classnames in upper camelcase.

item.title: Feedback plz
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:6, topic:553909”][quote author=z link=topic=672831.msg4499298#msg4499298 date=1448152719]
I was trying to make the Set generic, but it was complaining about generic array creation. I guess I’ll have to use something other than an array as the internal structure of the set, right?
[/quote]The actual problem is that “set” is just an interface; there are various ways to implement a set with Hashset being the most common[/quote]Looking through the implementation notes of HashSet, apparently HashSets are implemented using HashMaps, and HashMaps are implemented using “binned hash tables”, but when the tables get too large, then TreeMaps are used. Jesus

Read full topic
